com.xhive.index.interfaces
Interface XhiveIndexNodeFilterIf

All Superinterfaces:
NodeFilter
public interface XhiveIndexNodeFilterIf
extends NodeFilter

The XhiveIndexNodeFilterIf interface should be implented whenever you want to build an index. Each node from a document that is being indexed is passed through the filter. When the node is accepted by the filter, the filter is asked which keys need to be assigned to the node, after which the node is stored in the index.

The code below is an example of an filter that build an index of all speakers in a play, and their lines of text. 

 
 public class SpeakerIndexFilter implements XhiveIndexNodeFilterIf {

   private static final String SPEAKER = "SPEAKER";

   private Vector v = new Vector();

   public short acceptNode(Node n) {
     if (SPEAKER.equals(n.getNodeName())){
       return FILTER_ACCEPT;
     }
     return FILTER_SKIP;
   }

   //Gets the key of the accepted node
   public Vector getKeys(Node n) {
     v.removeAllElements();
     v.addElement(n.getFirstChild().getNodeValue());
     return v;
   }
 }

(c) X-Hive Corporation B.V. (www.x-hive.com)

Since:
X-Hive/DB 1.1

Methods inherited from interface org.w3c.dom.traversal.NodeFilter
acceptNode
 

Method Detail

getKeys

java.util.Vector<java.lang.String> getKeys(Node node)
This method is called by the indexing process to ask which keys need to beassigned to the node that is indexed.

Parameters:
node - The node that is indexed
Returns:
A vector containing all the keys that need to be assigned to the node that is indexed. For performance reasons it is better to build the filter in such a way that the vector returned is reused by the filter. The indexing process just reads the vector and does not use it. Reusing the vector will keep the number of objects created lower which is better for performance.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 1.1
